dt: {bc}being only partly in existence or operation {bc}{sx|incipient||}

dt.t: misty, {wi}inchoate{/wi} suspicions that all is not well with the nation

et: borrowed from Latin {it}incohātus, inchoātus{/it} "only begun, unfinished, imperfect," from past participle of {it}incohāre{/it} "to start work on, begin, initiate," perhaps, if the original sense was "to yoke a plow to a team of oxen," from {it}in-{/it} {et_link|in-:2|in-:2} + {it}-cohāre,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}cohum{/it} "hollow in the middle of a yoke into which a pole is fitted" or "strap used to attach the pole to the yoke," of uncertain origin

The word {it}cohum{/it} is known only from the work of the grammarians {et_link|varro|Varro:b} and Sextus Pompeius Festus, and their definitions may have been influenced by the presumed etymologies. Varro, who took the word to mean "hollow in the middle of a yoke" ("sub jugo medio cavum"), may have associated it with {it}cavum{/it} "cavity, hole," which he uses as the genus term. Festus, who defines it as a strap or thong ({it}lorum{/it}), associates it with {it}cohibēre{/it} "to hold together, keep in place." If these meanings are correct, {it}cohum{/it} may be linked to a putative western Indo-European verbal base {it}*kag{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} "grasp, enclose" (see the note at {et_link|haw:1|haw:1}), with an {it}o{/it} of secondary origin. But given the lack of textual evidence for {it}cohum,{/it} any etymology must remain speculative.
shortdef: being only partly in existence or operation : incipient; especially : imperfectly formed or formulated : formless, incoherent
